coursetitle: Gross Anatomy of Head and Neck and Neuro Anatomy
topics: Osteology of the skull, mandible & the cervical vertebrae
The neck (skin, fascia, superficial vessels and nerves)
The deep vessels and nerves of the neck
Lymphatic drainage of the Head and Neck
Gross features of the brain (sulci, gyri, sensory and motor areas)
External features & core structures of a cerebrum, cerebellum or brainstem
The peripheral nervous system (cranial and spinal nerves)
Autonomic nervous system (sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems)
Introduction to pathways in the CNS: Nuclei, projections, associations, and commissural pathways
Cerebrospinal fluid: formation, composition, circulation, function, clinical considerations, and the ventricular system
Blood supply to the central nervous system
aim: This course aims to provide students with a detailed understanding of the gross anatomy of the head and neck, as well as neuroanatomy.
Please check the textbook

topics: Creativity and Innovation for Business Success
Opportunities for Entrepreneurs and Human Resources Management
Small Business Management and Feasibility Studies
Legal Issues in Small Business Management in Nigeria
Business Case Study and Case Methodology
aim: Having a course such as this - Introduction to Entrepreneurial skills, as a tool for entrepreneurship education would go a long way in creating awareness of the entrepreneurship space in the country, as well as introducing the students to the necessary skills and mindsets that would set them on the course of impacting the country's economy. The expectation is that students at the end of this course, GES 301 (Introduction to Entrepreneurial Skills) would acquire the needed basic skills to be wealth and job creators

Learners will be equipped with requisite theoretical knowledge of public health nutrition problems as well as develop their capacity to provide effective and sustainable solutions at the community and population levels
topics: Frameworks in Nutrition, causes of malnutrition
Nutrition and Development; Population and demographic issues. Effect of malnutrition on nhealth, physical and mental development
Aetiology, Causes, Prevention and Intervention programmes to address Protein Energy Malnutrition
Aetiology, Causes, Prevention and intervention programmes to address Micronutrient deficiencies and other emerging nutritional problems of public health importance
Micronutrient deficiencies control (fortification, supplementation, and dietary diversification)
Maternal and Child Nutrition - Importance and Current situation in Nigeria

Management of children with various conditions such as cerebral palsy, infantile brachial plexus injuries, spina bifida, acute flaccid paralysis, post-immobilization stiffness, progressive muscular dystrophy, Down's syndrome
Communication of treatment goals, plans, exercise home assignments, and advice to parents/carers
objectives: Demonstrate skills in history taking and physical examination in paediatric disorders
Demonstrate skills in analysing clinical data, setting of goals and identifying treatment outcomes for paediatric conditions
Demonstrate skills in communicating management plan with parents/carers
Demonstrate skills in managing paediatric conditions commonly seen in physiotherapy clinics
aim: The aim of this clinical posting is to provide students with practical experience in paediatric physiotherapy. By the end of the posting, students should be able to demonstrate skills in history taking, physical examination, clinical analysis, communication with parents/carers, and management of paediatric conditions commonly seen in physiotherapy clinics.

topics: Treatment and evaluation of patients with orthopaedic conditions such as fractures, dislocations, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, back pain, neck pain, spinal stenosis, soft tissue injuries
Communication of treatment goals and plans to patients
objectives: Take history, carry out physical examination and other relevant assessment procedures on patients with orthopaedic conditions
Demonstrate skills in clinical reasoning and in making clinical judgments in different orthopaedic conditions
Demonstrate skills in communicating treatment goals and plans with patients with orthopaedic conditions
Demonstrate skills in managing and evaluating patients with orthopaedic conditions commonly seen in physiotherapy
aim: The aim of this clinical posting is to provide students with practical experience in orthopaedic physiotherapy. By the end of the posting, students should be able to demonstrate skills in history taking, physical examination, clinical reasoning, communication with patients, and management of orthopaedic conditions commonly seen in physiotherapy.

coursetitle: Introduction to Physiotherapy Profession and Practice
topics: Definition, philosophy, and scope of Physiotherapy
Historical development abroad and in Nigeria including major contributors
Roles of physiotherapy in promotion, preservation, and restoration of physical function
Codes of ethics of physiotherapy professional bodies
Musculoskeletal assessment and manual muscle testing
Importance and rights of patients and family in healthcare
Responsibilities of the clinician and the patient
Emotional responses to and strategies for managing patient behavior
objectives: Define physiotherapy and describe its scope
List criteria for professionalism
Describe the code of ethics in general healthcare and physiotherapy profession
Discuss ethical issues in physiotherapy and clinical practice in general
Describe the steps and requirements for clinical decision making
Describe methods and benefits of health information documentation
Take history from patients/carers, perform manual muscle test and musculoskeletal assessment and make inferences from information collected
Explain the importance of teamwork
Define evidence-based practice (EBP)
Identify the components of EBP
Enumerate the importance of EBP
aim: This course aims to introduce students to the profession and practice of physiotherapy, covering topics such as the definition and scope of physiotherapy, professionalism, ethical principles, clinical decision making, documentation methods, evidence-based practice, and the importance of teamwork.

topics: Bio-mechanical principles as related to human motion
Relationship of anatomical structures to physical functions
Range of muscle work (inner, middle and outer)
Group action of muscles agonists, antagonists, fixators, synergists etc
Principles of motion and force as applied to the body at rest and in motion
Muscular analysis of common activities of daily living
Methods of kinetic and kinematic gait analysis
Range of motion and causes of limitation
Types of instruments for and methods of measuring range of joint motion
objectives: Analyse muscle work involved in common activities of daily living
Discuss the importance of group actions of muscles
Analyze normal human gait
Apply biomechanical principles to modify human motion
Measure ranges of motion of peripheral and spinal joints
aim: This course aims to provide students with an understanding of biomechanical principles related to human motion, including muscle work, muscle contraction, group actions of muscles, principles of motion and force, analysis of human gait, and methods of measuring range of joint motion.

topics: Review of food substrates & final common pathway of metabolism
Body system responses to acute exercise
Physiological adjustments or adaptations of body systems to chronic exercise in health and disease
Concept of wellness and health promotion
Physical fitness in health and disease - definition, assessment methods, and exercise training programmes
Body composition assessment - anthropometry, somatotyping, adiposity indices
Body size classifications and weight control programmes
objectives: Describe the energy systems of the body
Explain the physiological basis of exercise testing and prescription
Describe physiological adjustments to acute and chronic exercises
Assess and evaluate patients/clients for physical fitness/weight control programmes
aim: This course aims to provide students with an understanding of exercise physiology, including the energy systems of the body, physiological responses to acute and chronic exercise, assessment of physical fitness and weight control programmes, and concepts of wellness and health promotion.

topics: Basic concepts in pain measurement in humans
General principles of pain evaluation and management
Drug treatment - NSAIDS, antidepressants, anticonvulsants, opioids, nerve blockers

Physiotherapy/Rehabilitation - dry needling, TENS, interferential current, electro-analgesic methods, cold and heat modalities, manipulation and massage, therapeutic exercises, behavioral interventions
Multidisciplinary pain management - contributions of other health professionals
objectives: Describe the anatomy and physiology of pain and pain transmission
Explain pain modulation and enumerate physiotherapy modalities for pain modulation
Discuss drug and other methods of pain management
aim: The course aims to provide students with an understanding of pain and pain control, including the anatomy and physiology of pain, pain measurement, psychosocial aspects, drug treatment, and physiotherapy modalities for pain modulation.

topics: Mobility or Range of Motion (ROM) exercises
Application of techniques to different body regions
objectives: Describe the general goals of exercise therapy
Classify exercises and differentiate between fundamental and derived starting positions
Describe the goals, indications, precautions, and contraindications to mobility/ROM, resistance, and stretching exercises
Explain the principles and physiological responses to muscle strengthening
aim: The course aims to provide students with an understanding of exercise therapy, including the goals of therapeutic exercise, classification of exercises, techniques for mobility/ROM and resistance exercises, and physiological responses to muscle strengthening.

objectives: Identify anatomical structures in the body
Explain the physiology of the human body, including the integration of the nervous, muscular, and cardiovascular systems
Understand the clinical aspects of the human body
aim: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to physiology with a focus on clinical relevance, linking gross anatomy to physiological functions. It covers the clinical aspects of each body system to form a basis for physiotherapy treatment, tying anatomical information directly to realistic clinical scenarios.

topics: Drug Absorption, Distribution, Metabolism, and Excretion
Anatomy and Physiology of Autonomic Transmission
Pharmacology of Conditions Commonly Seen in Physiotherapy
objectives: Describe routes of drug administration and anatomy and physiology of drug transmission
Differentiate between the uses of opioids and other types of pain relieving drugs
Identify and explain the actions of drugs used in conditions commonly seen in physiotherapy
Explain how drugs may facilitate or hinder physiotherapy procedures
aim: This course provides an understanding of pharmacology relevant to physiotherapy practice. It covers the scope of pharmacology, routes of drug administration, drug actions and interactions, and the anatomy and physiology of autonomic transmission. Students learn about drugs commonly used in physiotherapy, including pain relievers, muscle relaxants, and local anaesthetics.

coursetitle: Electrotherapy I: Conductive Heat & Cold and Therapeutic Ultrasound
topics: Human Body Isotherms and Thermal Regulation
Physical Principles of Heat and Cold Modalities
Physiological Responses to Heat and Cold Application
Therapeutic Uses, Indications, and Contraindications of Heat and Cold Modalities
Selection of Modalities for Specific Conditions
Physical Principles Governing the Use of Ultrasound
Methods and Procedures of Ultrasound Application
Therapeutic Uses and Indications of Ultrasound
Contraindications and Safety Measures for Ultrasound
objectives: Describe human body isotherms and thermal regulation
Discuss basic principles governing the application and uses of ultrasound, conductive heat, and cold modalities
Describe physiological effects, uses, indications, and contraindications of ultrasound, conductive heat, and cold modalities
Justify selection of modalities for specific conditions
aim: This course introduces students to the principles and applications of conductive heat and cold modalities, as well as therapeutic ultrasound in physiotherapy. Students learn about human body temperature regulation, physical principles of modalities, and their therapeutic uses, indications, and contraindications. They also gain the ability to select appropriate modalities for specific conditions.

coursetitle: Electrotherapy II: Electromagnetic Rays and Energy
topics: Electromagnetic Spectrum and Components Used in Electrotherapy
Basic Principles of Electromagnetic Rays and Energy
Therapeutic Uses and Indications of Electromagnetic Modalities
Contraindications and Safety Measures for Electromagnetic Modalities
Justification for Selection of Modalities for Specific Conditions
Generation and Description of Infrared Rays
Generation and Description of Ultraviolet Rays
Generation and Description of Continuous and Pulsed Electromagnetic Energy (Shortwave Diathermy)
Principles of Application and Methods and Procedures
objectives: Describe the electromagnetic spectrum and identify components used in electrotherapy
Discuss basic principles governing the application and uses of electromagnetic rays and energy
Describe physiological effects, uses, indications, and contraindications of each electromagnetic rays/energy modality
Justify selection of modalities for specific conditions
aim: This course provides students with knowledge of electromagnetic rays and energy used in electrotherapy. Students learn about the electromagnetic spectrum, basic principles of application, physiological effects, therapeutic uses, and contraindications of each modality. They also develop the ability to select appropriate modalities for specific conditions.

topics: Historical Development of Massage as a Modality in Physiotherapy
Application of Various Massage Manipulations to Body Regions
Adjunct Therapies: Postural Drainage, Bandaging, Limb Elevation
objectives: Explain what massage is and differentiate between various types of massage manipulations
Discuss indications and contraindications to massage
Apply appropriate massage manipulations to different body regions and for specific conditions
Describe the principles of myofascial release and reflexology
aim: This course provides students with a comprehensive understanding of massage therapy as a modality in physiotherapy. Students learn about the historical development, definition, and classification of massage, along with its physiological effects, therapeutic uses, indications, and contraindications. They also gain practical skills in applying various massage manipulations to different body regions and for specific conditions, as well as understanding specialized techniques such as myofascial release and reflexology.

topics: Guidelines for Therapeutic Exercises in Managing Osteoarthritis & Rheumatoid Arthritis
Therapeutic Exercises for Common Musculoskeletal Conditions in Various Body Parts
Therapeutic Exercises for Patients Undergoing Surgical Procedures
Special Areas of Therapeutic Exercise: Pregnancy and Postpartum Periods, Pulmonary Diseases, Weak Pelvic Floor Muscles
objectives: Describe guidelines for therapeutic exercises in managing various types of conditions
Describe guidelines for therapeutic exercises in managing patients undergoing surgical procedures
Describe precautions and contraindications to therapeutic exercises for various conditions
Develop and instruct patients in exercise programmes for various conditions and body parts
aim: This course aims to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary to design and implement exercise therapy programmes for various conditions and body parts. Students learn general principles and guidelines for therapeutic exercises, including management of osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, musculoskeletal conditions, surgical procedures, neurological conditions, vascular conditions, and special populations such as pregnant and postpartum women, individuals with pulmonary diseases, and those with weak pelvic floor muscles.

coursetitle: Manual Therapy II: Spinal and Peripheral Joint Mobilization
topics: Indications and Contraindications to Joint Mobilization
Specific Mobilization Techniques for Different Body Parts
Manual Traction for Cervical and Lumbar Spine
objectives: Differentiate between mobilization and manipulation and between physiological and accessory motion
Explain the basic concepts of joint motion
Enumerate the indications for and contraindications to joint mobilization
Describe the procedure (including concave-convex rule) for and apply joint mobilization to different parts of the body
Describe the different approaches to spinal mobilization (manipulation)
aim: This course aims to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to perform spinal and peripheral joint mobilization techniques effectively and safely. Students will learn about the definitions of joint mobilization, physiological and accessory motions, basic concepts of joint motion, indications and contraindications to joint mobilization, procedures for applying joint mobilization, specific mobilization techniques for different body parts, manual traction for cervical and lumbar spine, safety considerations before mobilizations, and approaches to spinal mobilization/ manipulation.

topics: Definition and Classification of Motor Skills
Analysis of Normal and Abnormal Human Postures
Identification and Analysis of Abnormal Human Gait and Motor Skills in Specific Conditions
Clinical Application of Motor Skills in Various Conditions
Corrective Therapy for Abnormal Human Motions and Postures
Ambulation Aids and Gait Patterns Using Assistive Devices
objectives: Analyze and compare normal and abnormal human motions including gait
Differentiate between gross and fine motor skills
Describe corrective therapy for abnormal motor skills
Describe different types of ambulation aids and identify their indications
Correctly prescribe and train gait patterns with ambulation aids
aim: This course aims to provide students with an understanding of pathokinesiology, focusing on the analysis of normal and abnormal human motions, motor skills, and postures. Students will learn to differentiate between gross and fine motor skills, analyze and compare normal and abnormal human motions including gait, prescribe corrective therapy for abnormal motor skills, identify different types of ambulation aids and their indications, and prescribe and train gait patterns with ambulation aids.

objectives: Make all necessary preparations (tray, patients, machine) prior to application of electrotherapy modalities
Demonstrate skills in communicating relevant information to simulated patients prior to applying electrotherapy modalities
Demonstrate skills in applying each electrotherapy modality
Demonstrate skills in documenting treatment given to simulated patients
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with practical skills in the application of electrotherapy modalities. By the end of the course, students should be able to make all necessary preparations prior to applying electrotherapy modalities, communicate relevant information to simulated patients, apply each electrotherapy modality effectively, and document treatment given to simulated patients.

objectives: Demonstrate skills in selecting appropriate exercises for different purposes and specific conditions
Demonstrate skills in instructing simulated patients in exercises
Provide progression in an exercise programme
Measure range of motion of peripheral and spinal joints
Analyze motor skills involved in Activities of Daily Living (ADLs)
Identify and correct abnormal gait and other motor skills in different conditions
Instruct and train simulated patients in various crutch gaits
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with practical skills in exercise therapy and kinesiology. By the end of the course, students should be able to select appropriate exercises for different purposes and conditions, instruct simulated patients in exercises, provide progression in exercise programs, measure range of motion, analyze motor skills in ADLs, identify and correct abnormal gait and motor skills, and instruct patients in various crutch gaits.

objectives: Demonstrate skills in applying massage manipulations for different purposes and to different parts of the body
Perform mobilization techniques to major peripheral joints
Describe the techniques of spinal manipulations
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with practical skills in manual therapy. By the end of the course, students should be able to apply massage manipulations for different purposes and body parts, perform mobilization techniques on major peripheral joints, and describe techniques of spinal manipulations.

topics: Physical agents in injury and disease
Drug, chemical and radiation induced injuries
Atrophy, hypertrophy, degeneration, oedema, thrombosis, infarction
Bacterial and viral diseases, fungal infections
aim: This course covers the pathology of diseases, including the cellular basis, inflammation, healing, immune mechanisms, and various types of injuries. It also discusses bacterial and viral diseases, neoplasia, and inherited diseases.
